title.narrative: FAO resilience rapid respons Burkina Faso 2018-2021
FAO resilience rapid respons Burkina Faso 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Project name: "Réponse d’urgence et appui à l’amélioration de la résilience des populations vulnérables dans les zones à risque du Burkina Faso 2018-2021" ("Urgent response aiming at strengthening the resilience of vulnerabe households in risk zones in Burkina Faso 2018-2020"). The FAO project code is OSRO/BKF/801/SWE.
Agreement partner and implementor: Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), United Nations
Implementation period: 1 June 2018 - 31 December 2021
Amount of financial support by Sida: 189 000 000 SEK
Background:
In Burkina Faso, poor rainfall distributions in recent years have reduced the area of cereal crops and the income generated by agriculture. Large production deficits are recorded every year in some parts of the country, particularly the northern regions. The production of natural grazing is becoming weaker from year to year, causing animal feeding difficulties for livestock, especially during the period of March to June of each year.
Thus, the analysis of crop production in recent years shows an instability of food availability and nutrition in the whole country.
The 2017/2018 crop year was marked by prolonged pockets of drought, Armyworm attacks in all parts of the country and grain-eating birds attacks in the Sahel, East and Boucle du Mouhoun regions.
The joint SAP-GTP mission in October 2017 counted 83 municipalities at risk. Thus, the current crop year 2017-2018 cereal production was estimated to have decreased with 12% compared to the average for the last five years.
It is against this backdrop that the Government of Burkina Faso developed a Plan of Emergency and Support to Vulnerable Populations for the year 2018. In addition to this, a Plan of Emergency and 2018 Resilience Initiative for Burkina Faso was developed by the UN System and its humanitarian partners in Burkina Faso.
The project reaches 28,000 poor and very poor households (according to the HEA classification) in the coverage regions, all of whom will benefit from the unconditional cash transfer during the lean season. In addition to unconditional cash transfer, 4100 self-selected households will have the opportunity to enroll in the «Cash for Work" activities (i.e. rehabilitation of communal infrastructures) during the mitigation and recovery period. Moreover, according to their main livelihoods, all households (HH) will receive productive assets: 2800 HH cereal production, 2500 HH small livestock restocking (sheep, goats, poultry, pigs depending on the choice), 1900 HH with livestock feed coupons and 2500 HH for market gardening coupled with nutritious gardens to strengthen their resilience. All targeted households (10 000) will also benefit from a nutritional education/sensitization programme.
The beneficiaries of the project will be identified on the already existing database relating to the socio-economic situation and the mapping of the various stakeholders.
Among the targeted beneficiaries, special emphasis will be placed on women and young people in order to take into account their specific needs.
Development objective: The resilience of vulnerable pastoralists and agro-pastoralists to climate and economic shocks is improved.
Specific objectives: 1 Vulnerable households improve their access to food and livelihoods. 2 The livelihoods of vulnerable agro-sylvo-pastoral households in the provinces heavily affected by the crisis in Burkina Faso is reconstituted. 3 The nutritional condition of vulnerable households in provinces heavily affected by the crisis in Burkina Faso is improved.
The initial agreement had an activity period from 1 June 2018 to 31 May 2020 and a budget of 79 million SEK. The agreement was amended at end 2019 with a budget increase up to 129 million SEK. A second amendment was made at end 2020 with an extension of the activity period to 31 December 2021 and a budget increase up to the total of 189 million SEK. The amendments are justified by the dramatic increase of need for support to the local population due the worsened security situation and the increase of the number of internally displaced people to more than one million.

Projektnamn: "Réponse d'urgence et appui à l'amélioration de la résilience des populations vulnérables dans les zones à risque du Burkina Faso 2018-2021" ("Akut svar för att stärka moståndskraften hos utsatta hushåll i riskzoner i Burkina Faso 2018-2021"). FAO:s projektkod är OSRO/BKF/801/SWE.
Avtalspartner och genomförare: Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), FN
Genomförandeperiod: 1 juni 2018 - 31 december 2021
Finansiellt stöd från Sida: 189 000 000 SEK
Bakgrund:
I Burkina Faso har den i tid och rum ojämnt spridda nederbörden under de senaste åren minskat den odlade arealen och den inkomst som genereras av jordbruket. Stora produktionsunderskott registreras varje år i delar av landet, särskilt i de norra regionerna. Foderproduktionen från naturliga betesmarker blir också svagare från år till år, vilket medför problem för boskap, särskilt under perioden mars till juni. Tillgången på mat har därmed blivit instabil i hela landet.
Odlingssäsongen 2017/2018 präglades av långvariga fickor av torka samt attacker av insekter i hela landet, och av fröätande fåglar i stora områden.
Det gemensamma SAP-GTP-uppdraget i oktober 2017 klassade 83 kommuner i riskzonen för matosäkerhet och visade att skörden 2017-2018 minskade med 12% jämfört med genomsnittet för de senaste fem åren.
Mot den bakgrunden formulerade Burkina Fasos regering en nödplan för stöd till utsatta befolkningar för år 2018. Utöver detta togs planen ”2018 Resilience Initiative for Burkina Faso” fram av FN: s system och dess humanitära partners i Burkina Faso.
Det aktuella FAO-projektet bistår ca 28000 fattiga och mycket fattiga hushåll (enligt HEA-klassificeringen) i det täckta området, vilka alla kommer att dra nytta av överföringen av "unconditional cash" under de svåra månaderna före skörd. Förutom "unconditional cash" kommer 4100 hushåll ha möjlighet att anmäla sig till aktiviteterna "Cash for Work" (dvs. rehabilitering av kommunala infrastrukturer) under höst och torrperiod. Dessutom kommer hushållens egna produktiva kapacitet att stärkas genom utdelning av "produktions-kits": 2800 kits för spannmålsproduktion, 2500 kits för uppfödning av boskap (får, getter, fjäderfä, grisar beroende på valet), 1900 hushåll får djurfoderkuponger och 2500 hushåll får stöd i grönsaksodling för att stärka nutrition och motståndskraft. Alla hushåll i målgruppen kommer också att dra nytta av utbildning i nutrition.
Mottagarna (hushållen) kommer att identifieras i den existerande databasen över sårbara hushåll.
Bland mottagarna kommer särskild tonvikt läggas på kvinnor och unga och deras specifika behov.
Utvecklingsmål: De sårbara pastoralisternas och agro-pastoralisternas motståndskraft mot klimat och ekonomiska chocker förbättras.
Specifika mål: 1 Sårbara hushåll förbättrar sin tillgång till mat och försörjning. 2 Egenförsörjningen hos sårbara agro-sylvo-pastorala hushåll i de provinser som drabbats hårt av krisen i Burkina Faso har återställts. 3 De sårbara hushållens nutrition i provinser som drabbats hårt av krisen i Burkina Faso har förbättrats. Det initiala avtalet mellan ambassaden och FAO sträckte sig fram till 31 maj 2020 för en budget om 79 miljoner kr. Hösten 2019 ökades budgeten till 129 miljoner kr. Hösten 2020 ökades den ytterligare till 189 miljoner kr och aktivitetsperioden förlängdes till 31 december 2021. Skälet till budgetökningen var det dramatiskt ökade behovet av stöd till befolkningen i norra landet pga den tilltagande säkerhetskrisen och den stora ökningen av internflyktingar (drygt en miljon under hösten 2020).

Utvecklingsmål Motståndskraften mot klimatchocker och ekonomiska chocker hos sårbara boskapsskötare och agro-pastoralister har förbättrats Specifika mål 1 Sårbara hushåll har förbättrad tillgång till mat och försörjning 2 Försörjningsförmågan hos sårbara agro-sylvo-pastorala hushåll i krisdrabbade provinser har återställts 3 De sårbara hushållens näringsstatus i krisdrabbade provinser i Burkina Faso har förbättrats

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: REGARDING THE NARRATIVE ANNUAL REPORT 2020 The main results during 2020 were as follows: RESULT 1 (Vulnerable households have improved their access to food and production means) : - 8700 households were added to the target group - 12 MSEK were distributed as inconditional cash to IDPs and host families - 1.7 MSEK were paid out as cash for work - Soil conservation work was carried out on approximately 860 hectares, rice fields established on 105 ha and 218 compost piles were established. - 4 "Post distribution minitoring studies" (PDMs) were carried out and presented interesting results: * The variety of consumed food has increased * Food security has improved * Inconditional cash was used mostly for (i) food, (ii) purchase of animals, (iii) Schools/education, (iv) rent or building materiel and (v) agricultural inputs * in 2/3 of the households the male head decides on how to use the cash * 95% of the distributed cash is used for the nuclear family RESULT 2 (The agro-sylvo-pastoral capital of vulnerable households is reconsituted) : - 5000 households received 750 tons of animal fodder - 646 tons of fodder was put into "fodder banks" - 8164 cattle and 16357 sheep and goat were vaccinated (66% of the target) -870 ha of vegetable and non-timber forest products sites were rehabilitated - 140 tons of fertilizer, 6488 kg of sorgho seeds, 14000 kg of bean seeds and 1178 kg of millet seeds were distributed to households - 19 sites for rice production were installed with a total area of 500 hectares - 140 kg of Moringa seeds, 140 kg of babobab seeds, 56 kg of tomate seeds and 210 kg of onion seeds were distributed to households - 2800 households were trained on production with improved cereal varieties and 500 female head of households were trained on production, protection and conservation of niébé beans RESULT 3 (The nutritional situation of vulnerable households has improved) - Training has been done for 20 000 households No unexpected results were noted. GENERAL COMMENTS A general comment on the FAO reporting is that most of the content is descriptions of activities, numbers relating to activities and direct results from the PDMs. In the reporting, the analysis is practically absent. It would have been valuable to read an analysis of gender aspects, on the sustainability of the actions, on how the conflict has influenced activities, how the contribution could possibly reduce the conflict risk and how well the contribution methodology could serve as a model for futur "nexus" or "triple-nexus" interventions. An email was sent to FAO with such comments on 20210505. No reply received as yet. However, some of these questions will be raised at the Annual Review meeting at the end of July 2021 and during the field visit in conjunction to the meeting. FAO apparently sees the project as an interesting model for a nexus approach. However, the sustainabiity of its actions raises a question mark. A "one-off" support to vulnerable households through handing out of inputs combined with short training sessions, will it have a lasting effect on the resilience of these households? This is one of the issues that should be analysed by the final evaluation planned for at end 2021. It seems important that the Embassy takes part in the evaluation, both by contributing to its terms of reference and by recruiting a consultant that joins the team recruited by FAO. Another issue that should be analysed is whether a project like this could contribute more activley to a triple-nexus approach, by not only linking humanitarian support to development also preventing conflict.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
